statement.text: Venous reflux is quantified using duplex ultrasound with patient standing, measuring reflux duration after calf compression release or Valsalva, with >0.5 seconds in superficial veins and >1.0 second in deep veins defining pathologic reflux.

explanation.intuition: To check if vein valves work, you squeeze the calf to push blood up, then release and watch if it flows backward. Normal valves snap shut in less than half a second. Incompetent valves let blood fall back down, creating prolonged reverse flow.
explanation.key_insight: Reflux duration thresholds differ by vein type. Superficial veins (GSV/SSV) use 0.5 second cutoff while deep veins use 1.0 second because deep veins normally have longer valve closure times.
explanation.technical_details: Technique: patient standing, duplex probe on vein segment, elicit reflux by calf compression release or Valsalva (proximal segments). Measure: peak reflux velocity, reflux duration. Thresholds: superficial veins >0.5 sec, deep veins >1.0 sec, perforators >0.5 sec with diameter >3.5mm. Severity: correlates with reflux duration and number of segments involved. Documentation: map all incompetent segments for treatment planning.

clinical_features.technique: Standing patient, calf compression release with duplex imaging
clinical_features.documentation: Map all incompetent segments for treatment planning

clinical_pearls: Superficial threshold: >0.5 sec; Deep threshold: >1.0 sec
Patient MUST be standing - supine falsely underestimates reflux
Map all incompetent segments for comprehensive treatment planning
